children.subject: Same. I've interviewed at 2 startups and received offers from both (one of them from MIT), while with bigger companies I almost never get beyond round 2.

If by startups you mean private companies of any size? I had offers from big tech companies and small unicorns, and I can definitely say that my interviews at the unicorns were much much more difficult than my interviews at big tech companies. Furthermore, the unicorns may have a higher “bar” in that they require you to be near perfect in every round because otherwise they can easily find another applicant that was perfect in every round and choose them over you.

history.content:
Not all startups are the same. If the startups you're referring to are very popular (Robinhood, Stripe, Roblox, Nuro, Snowflake, etc), then their interviews are probably harder than FAANG. Idk but so far most big companies I've interviewed at just pull coding problems straight from Leetcode medium, which is very predictable. But with some startups you never know what they are expecting.

One way to judge this is by the offer packages they give you. If they are super competitive (130-150 base, 200K+ TC), then interviews are most likely gonna be harder for obvious reasons. But if the startup is giving you the whole spiel about them being cash-strapped with only 110 base for Bay Area, most likely that means they aren't looking to bring in the "smartest/most talented" new grads and they just want someone who can get the job done (supply and demand). This is just my experience, if anyone has anything else to add please do.

children.subject: Snap isn't a startup, or a unicorn for that matter. It's a publicly traded company.

There isn't a set answer -- some startup interviews could be easy and just talk about ur experiences. Some, like Snap, do heavy resume filtering and then ask LC hards in their interviews along with behavioral/situational qs.

You can generally research their total compensation package and if it is competitive with bigger companies, it is generally correlated with being heavily funded with high growth potential. This also means, by simple economics, the competition is going to be much tougher and they will only want the best. I've interned at 2 unicorns now and the level of difficulty in those interviews compared to my interviews at places like Amazon and Microsoft was off the charts.
how did you prepare for the multithreading + sys design questions?

@anon comp, mostly self-studied, read some articles online about good backend/system design. I know some companies like Netflix have engineering blogs, I found reading those and seeing some of the ideas they used pretty helpful as well
Ngl 162 helped me a lot with some OS interviews. Literally got interviewed on a concept I learned in lecture the day before.

Not sure about full time, but I currently have two internship offers, one from a "unicorn" and another from FAANG. The unicorn's interview questions were much much harder, with algorithms + multithreading + sys design while the FAANG company was just directly copied leetcode mediums.

history.content: Some say startups have higher bars because they want people to be able to do stuff immediately. But in reality I had gotten final interviews at 3 startups and received offer from two, but got ghosted by all the big companies. Wondering why. Also wondering whether there’s still a chance to get into big companies in this economy.
history.subject: Is it harder or easier to get into a startup than a big company?
